questions.text: The 8-year-old child with delayed development was referred for evaluation of recurrent infections. History is notable for the presence of congenital heart defects. Further examination reveals the presence of a cleft palate and workup reveals the presence of hypocalcemia.  Which component of the immune system is likely to be affected in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with developmental delay, recurrent infections with a history of congenital heart disease and examination revealing cleft palate and hypocalcemia point towards the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome. Cell-mediated immunity is affected.

DiGeorge syndrome is a complex embryopathy with an autosomal dominant inheritance that is caused by microdeletions in the long arm of chromosome 22, leading to multiple developmental defects.

Children with DiGeorge syndrome have thymic hypoplasia resulting in T-cell immunodeficiency. The disease may range from mildly increased susceptibility to infections to a severe disease requiring a thymic or hematopoietic stem cell transplant. Patients are generally able to cope with extracellular bacterial infections because their innate and T cell-independent antibody responses are intact, but they cannot effectively eliminate intracellular pathogens such as viruses, intracellular bacteria, and fungi.

The clinical features of this syndrome include:

  • Congenital heart disease- aortic arch anomalies
  • Abnormalities of the palate like cleft palate.
  • Facial dysmorphisms such as hypertelorism, antimongoloid slant, low set ears, micrognathia, short philtrum, and bifid uvula.
  • Thymic hypoplasia with impaired T cell immunity. 
  • Parathyroid hypoplasia resulting in hypocalcemia (tetany).

Interestingly individuals with DiGeorge syndrome are at high risk for psychotic illnesses such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorders.

Diagnosis is established only by the detection of deletion in long-arm chromosome 22 by fluorescent in-situ hybridisation(FISH).

 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with muscle weakness, abnormal tingling sensation over the face, and pain and swelling over the knee joint for 3 months. On examination, his blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Investigations show hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalciuria with metabolic alkalosis. His x-ray knee is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young male presenting with muscle weakness, paresthesia over the face, hypotension, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalciuria, metabolic alkalosis, and x-ray knee showing chondrocalcinosis as punctate density on the cartilage are suggestive of Gitelman's syndrome. 

Gitelman's syndrome is an autosomal recessive salt-losing renal tubulopathy. It occurs due to a mutation of Na+-Cl– co-transporter (NCCT) in the distal tubule. 

NCCT helps in the absorption of sodium and chloride ions from the lumen of the distal tubule. In Gitelman's syndrome, due to the loss of function of NCCT, there will be increased sodium and chloride delivery to collecting duct and volume retraction. This results in increased renin and aldosterone secretion. Aldosterone act on epithelial sodium channels in the collecting duct causing increased reabsorption of sodium and increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions leading to hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

Downregulation of magnesium-permeable channels in Gitelman syndrome leads to urinary loss of magnesium resulting in hypomagnesemia.

There is increased passive reabsorption of calcium in the proximal convoluted tubule in Gitelman syndrome resulting in hypocalciuria. 

Hypomagnesemia impairs the function of calcitropic hormones and down-regulates the normal inverse association between ionized calcium, parathyroid hormone, and calcitriol. This results in reduced skeletal sensitivity of PTH and impaired intestinal calcium transport and explains the lack of hypercalcemia response to hypocalciuria. 

Low magnesium levels result in the reduction of pyrophosphate activity that could promote pyrophosphate crystallization in joints causing joint pains and chondrocalcinosis.

Even though patients present above the age of 6 years, the diagnosis in most cases is established during adulthood. Patients often present with signs of tetany, paresthesias, and chondrocalcinosis, as a result of hypomagnesemia and fatiguability. 

Hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia prolong the duration of the action potential of cardiomyocytes and consequently increase the risk of ventricular arrhythmia. 

Other options:

Option A: Bartter's syndrome affects the Na+/K+/Cl-  co-transporter in the thick ascending loop of Henle. It causes hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria.

Option C: Liddle's syndrome causes increased activation of epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) channels expressed on the apical membrane of principal cells of the collecting duct. It results in severe hypertension with hypokalemia.

Option D: Fanconi's syndrome occurs due to a defect in the proximal tubular function that prevents the absorption of electrolytes and other substances that are normally absorbed by the proximal tubule. It results in hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be associated with Turner syndrome?
questions.solution:
Cubitus valgus, not cubitus varus, is associated with Turner syndrome.

Turner syndrome occurs due to complete or partial monosomy of X-chromosomes. It produces hypogonadism in phenotypic females. It is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females.

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome:

  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Streak ovaries, infertility, amenorrhea
  • Peripheral lymphedema at birth
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Pigmented nevi
  • Coarctation of aorta

questions.text: Infertility in Klinefelter's syndrome is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Infertility in Klinefelter’s syndrome is due to azoospermia i.e. a complete absence of sperm in the semen.

Klinefelter's syndrome is a genetic disorder that results from a 47, XXY karyotype. These patients are phenotypically male and present with infertility due to hyalinization of the seminiferous tubules and no spermatogenesis. Hence, the present with testes of small volume. They have manifestations of androgen deficiency such as average stature, sparse body hair, low libido, etc. Relatively elevated estradiol levels result in gynecomastia. Other features include possible thromboses, varicose veins, osteoporosis, etc. These patients are advised to undergo frequent mammography screening due to the increased breast cancer risk.

The most important treatment measure is with supplementation of testosterone. Dosage is decided on an individualized basis depending on the patient's current levels. 

Fertility can be achieved using the artificial reproductive technique of intracytoplasmic sperm injection from the patient into the egg of the partner. 

Other options-

Option (A): Asthenospermia is the cause of infertility in Kartagener’s syndrome, also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia. It presents with the classical triad of situs inversus, bronchiectasis, and chronic sinusitis. Asthenospermia is the decreased motility of spermatozoa due to abnormal ciliary motility seen in this syndrome. It occurs due to defects in the dynein arm of cilia. Ciliary motility is not affected in Klinefelter's syndrome.

Option (C): Undescended testes are not seen in patients with Klinefelter's syndrome.

Option (D): Epididymis obstruction can cause infertility due to sexually transmitted infections and congenital malformations. The most common organisms responsible for the infective etiology are C. trachomatis and N. gonorrheae. Coliform organisms can also be causative in men who have sex with men. This is not the cause of infertility in Klinefelter's syndrome.

questions.text: A child presents to you with an abdominal mass, hypertension, and hematuria. Which of the following statement is false about the syndromes associated with this condition?

choices.text: Trisomy 18 can result in cognitive impairment
Aniridia is associated with WAGR syndrome
Male abnormal genitalia is commonly seen in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome
Early-onset renal failure is characteristic of Denys-Drash syndrome

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of Wilms tumor. Male abnormal genitalia is associated with Denys-Drash syndrome and not with Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome. Both of these are syndromes associated with Wilm's tumor. 

Wilms tumor is the most common primary malignant renal tumor in children. After neuroblastoma, it is the second most common malignant abdominal tumor in childhood. The clinical presentation of Wilms tumor is an incidental discovery of asymptomatic abdominal mass, hypertension, abdominal pain, and gross painless hematuria. Pulmonary embolism can be a fatal complication. 

Wilm's tumor arises due to loss of function mutation of the WT1 (Wilm's tumor 1) gene. The syndromes associated with Wilms tumor are WAGR syndrome, Denys-Drash syndrome, Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome, Fraiser syndrome, Fanconi anemia, trisomy 18, and Perlman syndrome.

Noteworthy syndromes and their features are:

  • WAGR syndrome: Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary abnormalities, mental retardation
  • Denys-Drash syndrome: Early-onset renal failure, gonadal dysgenesis / male pseudohermaphroditism
  • Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome: Hemihypertrophy, organomegaly, macroglossia
  • Trisomy 18: Prominent occiput, cognitive impairment, hypertonia

Histologically, Wilms tumor is made of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cells. 

Wilms tumor is an example of small, round, blue-cell tumors that are malignant neoplasms that have a characteristic appearance under the microscope. Other examples include: 

  • Medulloblastoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

The diagnosis can be confirmed by radiological investigations like CT, abdominal ultrasound, and biopsy.

Surgery, and chemotherapy, with or without radiotherapy can be used for the management.

questions.text:
Match the following characteristic clinical appearances with the corresponding syndromes.
  1. Eagle-Barrett Syndrome
  2. Potter syndrome
  3. Treacher-Collins syndrome
  4. Down's syndrome
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C.

Down syndrome occurs due to trisomy of chromosome 21 leading to multisystem manifestations. There is a wide range of presentations. A few key features include characteristic facies such as flat face, epicanthal folds, small head, flat nasal bridge, upward slanting palpebral fissures, brushfield spots, small nose, protruding tongue, and small and lowset ears. Congenital heart defects can also be present. This patient has a normal karyotype.

The following image shows a child with Down syndrome:

Prune Belly Syndrome is also known as - Eagle-Barrett Syndrome, Triad Syndrome, Obrinsky Syndrome, and Frohlich Syndrome.

Prune Belly Triad -

  • Cryptorchidism
  • Abdominal Wall Defects
  • Genitourinary Defects

Features of Prune Belly Syndrome:

  • Flabby, Hypotonic & Thin Abdominal Wall - Due to deficient abdominal wall muscles
  • Urethral Obstruction in fetal life.
  • Predominantly seen in males

Associated defects:

  • Posterior urethral valve
  • Vesicoureteric Reflux
  • Limb Anomalies and scoliosis

Treatment :

  • Ureteric dilatation - not until an obstruction occurs
  • Bilateral orchidopexy - for cryptorchidism.
  • Abdominal wall reconstruction - performed in conjugation with orchidopexy at 6-12 months of age through abdominoplasty.

Potter Syndrome:

  • Bilateral Renal Agenesis leads to oligohydramnios, in turn causing pulmonary hypoplasia.
  • Resultant characteristic Potter Facies -
    • Widely separated eyes with epicanthic fold
    • Small, low-set ears
    • Flat & broad nose
    • Receding Chin
  • Limb Anomalies
  • Wrinkled Skin

Interestingly, the cause of death is pulmonary insufficiency from pulmonary hypoplasia, not renal failure.

 

 
 

Treacher Collins syndrome/ Mandibulofacial dysostosis refers to a condition resulting from the hypoplasia of the zygoma and mandible.

Ocular features:

  • Indistinct inferior orbital margin
  • Coloboma of the lower eyelid
  • Anti-mongoloid slant of palpebral fissures

Systemic features

  • Macrostomia with a high-arched palate
  • External ear deformity
  • Bird-like face

The image below shows features of Treacher Collins syndrome.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was brought to her pediatrician with complaints of repeated hand-wringing movements and finger-licking. Detailed history revealed regression of language milestones. Microcephaly was noted on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Rett syndrome based on the stereotyped hand-wringing movements, repetitive behavior with regressed language milestones, and microcephaly.

Rett syndrome is a progressive condition predominantly seen in girls. Under the international classification of diseases, the tenth revision falls under pervasive development disorder. The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual, 5th edition (DSM-5) considers it an autism spectrum disorder, though there are marked differences between them.

Between the ages of 6 months to 2 years, affected children develop progressive encephalopathy. Other clinical features include stereotypic hand movements such as wringing, biting, or licking the fingers, and poor muscle coordination. Marked regression of all language skills and plateaued communicative and social skills can also be seen. Microcephaly develops as age progresses. Head circumference is normal at birth, but growth begins to decelerate between the ages of 6 months to 1 year. Seizures are an associated feature in a large number of cases. 

Supportive treatment is given. Physiotherapy is beneficial for muscular dysfunction. Anticonvulsants may be required to control seizures.

Other options:

Options A&D: Heller's syndrome is a type of autism spectrum disorder. It is also known as childhood disintegrative disorder. It is predominantly seen in boys. They have marked regression in intellectual, social, and language functions after 2 years of apparently normal development. 

Option B: Asperger's syndrome is a type of autism spectrum disorder. There are marked nonverbal communicative gestures and failure to develop relationships with peers. No significant delay in language milestones or cognitive development is seen. The intelligence remains normal.

questions.text:
A researcher conducting multiple genetic studies observes that targeted mutations within certain genes can induce defects in DNA repair and dramatically increase susceptibility to cancer. Which of the following diseases is incorrectly matched with the DNA repair mechanisms?

SCID- Severe combined immunodeficiency.

choices.text: Xeroderma pigmentosum - Defective nucleotide excision repair
Lynch syndrome - Defective base excision repair

questions.solution:
Lynch syndrome, or hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), occurs due to a defective DNA mismatch repair mechanism. Defective DNA base excision repair is associated with MUTYH-associated polyposis.

HNPCC is an autosomal dominant genetic condition that is associated with a high risk of colon cancer as well as other cancers including endometrial cancer (second most common), cancers of the stomach, ovary, ureters, etc.

DNA mismatch repair proteins function as spell checkers during DNA replication by correcting the incorrect pairing. In HNPCC, the proofreading function of the mismatch repair systems (majorly MLH1 and MSH2) is lost, leading to the accumulation of errors throughout the genome. The genomes of these patients show microsatellite instability, which is characterized by changes in the length of short repeats.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presented with a prolonged history of fainting spells and palpitations. He is a known case of Brugada syndrome and has been started on quinidine for the same, after which he developed a cardiac rhythm, as shown in the ECG given below. Which of the following could be the diagnosis?

WPW: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome

AVNRT: Atrioventricular nodal reentry tachycardia

choices.text: Torsades  de pointes with QT prolongation

questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the given scenario is torsades de pointes with QT interval prolongation.

Quinidine can cause polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, or torsades de pointes, which has been shown in the given ECG. Quinidine is often used in the management of patients with Brugada syndrome, as a class I antiarrhythmic agent (Ia).

Torsades de pointes, which means “twisting of the points,” is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia characterized by the twisting of the QRS axis around the baseline and a polymorphic appearance. This rhythm is most commonly seen in association with hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia. There is QT interval prolongation in the ECG due to a non-uniform delay in repolarization.

Other cause of torsades de pointes:

  • Drugs like quinidine, procainamide, disopyramide, and phenothiazine (amiodarone is rarely associated with torsades de pointes because the delay in repolarization induced by it is uniform)
  • Bradycardia
  • Acute ischemia or infarction

Management:

  • Discontinue the offending drug
  • Correct electrolyte abnormalities, pH, and hypoxia
  • Magnesium sulfate infusion 
  • Increase the heart rate with electrical pacing, isoproterenol infusion, or intravenous atropine 

If the patient is hemodynamically stable, IV MgSO4 is the treatment of choice. IV MgSO4 is highly effective for both treatment and prevention of the recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades de pointes.

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, then immediate defibrillation should be done.

Brugada syndrome is a rare syndrome characterized by >0.2 mV of ST-segment elevation and negative T-wave in more than one anterior precordial lead (V1–V3).

Episodes of syncope or cardiac arrest are common due to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) in the absence of structural heart disease, as in Brugada syndrome. Cardiac arrest may occur during sleep or be provoked by febrile illness. Males are more commonly affected than females. Mutations involving cardiac sodium channels are identified in a quarter of cases. Quinidine has been used successfully to suppress frequent episodes of VT.

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: You are following up on a patient who is suspected to have Gradenigo's syndrome. Which of the following will not constitute a component of the classical triad of this condition?
questions.solution:
Gradenigo’s Syndrome generally occurs secondary to petrous apicitis. It is a complication of the attico-antral type of otitis media. Immobility of the homolateral soft palate (generally due to X cranial nerve palsy) is not a component of its classical triad of symptoms. 

Gradenigo’s syndrome is a triad that consists of:

  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (VI nerve palsy) - lateral rectus palsy
  • Deep ear/facial pain (V Nerve involvement)
  • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

Fever, headache, vomiting and sometimes neck rigidity may also be associated. Some patients may get facial paralysis and recurrent vertigo due to the involvement of facial and statoacoustic nerves.

Diagnosis of petrous apicitis requires both a CT scan and MRI. CT scan of temporal bone will show bony details of the petrous apex and the air cells while MRI helps to differentiate diploic marrow-containing apex from the fluid or pus.

Treatment with suitable intravenous antibacterial therapy should precede and follow surgical intervention. Definitive management would include mastoidectomy. 

Note - 

Trotter’s Triad:

  1. Conductive hearing loss
  2. Immobility of homolateral soft palate
  3. Trigeminal neuralgia

This is generally seen in Nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: A  primigravida was brought to the emergency department with the sudden onset of fever, altered mental status, confusion, and petechiae over both lower limbs. She has no history of similar episodes. Laboratory reports revealed thrombocytopenia, anaemia, features of acute kidney injury, and antibodies to ADAMTS13. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a primigravida who presents with sudden onset of fever, neurologic abnormalities(altered mental status, confusion), thrombocytopenia (petechiae over lower limbs), hemolytic anaemia, acute kidney injury and antibodies to  ADAMTS13 suggests the diagnosis of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).  

TTP is a thrombotic microangiopathy that can be inherited or spontaneously acquired. It results from a deficiency of, or antibodies to, the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which normally cleaves multimers of vWF. Failure to cleave these multimers results in abnormally large vWF multimers which activate platelets and lead to excessive platelet adhesion and aggregation. This causes platelet thrombi to form, and fibrin deposits to take place at various sites. These thrombi result in the classic pentad of clinical features: 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure
  • Neurologic findings
  • Fever

The platelet thrombi narrow the vessel lumen, causing shearing stress on the red blood cells that are passing through. This results in microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia. The same platelet thrombi cause microvascular occlusion and result in features like renal failure and neurological manifestations.

On peripheral smear, these fragmented red cells appear as schistocytes or helmet cells, as shown in the image below:

 

Timely diagnosis is important to prevent devastating outcomes like profuse bleeding and renal failure. The best method to treat these patients is using plasma exchange therapy. It should be continued until the platelet counts are back to normal and there are no signs of hemolysis for at least 2 days. Glucocorticoids can also be used along with this therapy. In refractory cases, rituximab, and caplacizumab an antiVWF nanobody decreases mortality when used in patients with ADAMTS13 <10%.

Other causes of microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia include:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (Most common)
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
  • Malignant hypertension
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Disseminated cancer 

Other options-

Option (A): Immune thrombocytopenic purpura occurs as a chronic disease in adults with several episodes over time, usually following infections. It presents as mucocutaneous bleeding and very low platelet counts. These patients have otherwise normal peripheral blood pictures.

Option (B): Disseminated intravascular coagulation refers to the widespread intravascular clot formation, commonly due to sepsis, trauma, and obstetric complications. These patients present with petechiae, ecchymoses, oozing from venipuncture sites, etc. They do not display the classic pentad seen in TTP. Schistocytes may be present on peripheral smear. Deranged clotting parameters are seen only in DIC and not in TTP.

Option (C): Hemolytic uremic syndrome is a disorder seen predominantly in children, following an episode of bloody diarrhea. Escherichia coli O157:H7 is most commonly the cause of this diarrhea. It can also present with acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia, but neurological manifestations are less common. ADAMTS13 levels are normal in a majority of patients. It can be low in some rare cases.

questions.text: All are true regarding Tumour Lysis Syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Hypocalcaemia (and not hypercalcemia) is seen in Tumour Lysis Syndrome (TLS).

Tumour Lysis Syndrome is caused by destruction of large number of rapidly multiplying neoplastic cells: Burkitt’s lymphoma, ALL, CLL on chemotherapy.

Acute hyperuricemic nephropathy occurs when urinary uric acid/urine creatinine >1.

  • Characteristic biochemical changes in TLS:
    • Hyperuricemia
    • Hyperkalaemia
    • Hypocalcaemia
    • Hyperphosphatemia
    • Acidosis
    • Acute renal failure
  • Drugs commonly associated are:
    • Fludarabine
    • Letrozole
    • Tamoxifen
    • Rituximab
    • Also, glucocorticoids
  • High risk for TLS:
    • Tumour burden
    • Hyperuricemia
    • High LDH
  • Treatment:
    • Allopurinol
    • Rasburicase, a recombinant urate oxidase (contraindicated in G6PD deficiency, can cause bronchospasm, hypotension, and hypoxia).
    • Aggressive treatment with ½ N.S
    • Urinary alkalization to pH >7 with sodium bicarbonate.
    • Hemodialysis/hemofiltration if:
      • S. potassium > 6
      • S. uric acid > 10
      • S. phosphate > 10
      • S. creatinine >10 with severe hypocalcaemia.

questions.text: In Guillain-Barre syndrome of Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) variant, the complement deposition occurs at _______
questions.solution:
In AIDP, complement deposits along the outer surface of the Schwann cell.

Activation of complement initiates a characteristic vesicular disintegration of the myelin sheath and also leads to recruitment of activated macrophages, which participate in damage to myelin and axons.

In AMAN the complement along with IgG is deposited at the nodes of Ranvier of large motor axons.

questions.text: A young girl presents to you with delayed puberty. On examination, you notice a characteristic finding, as shown in the picture below. Apart from this, she has a shield-shaped chest. Investigations revealed the presence of normal gonads and pulmonary valvular stenosis. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical diagnosis based on features of short, webbed neck; shield chest; normal gonads; and pulmonary valvular stenosis is Noonan syndrome.

Noonan syndrome follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. It involves mutations of the components of the RAS mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway (RAS-MAPK) pathway. The most common of these mutations is that of PTPN11, which encodes a protein tyrosine phosphatase on chromosome 12. Although it shares many clinical features with Turner syndrome, Noonan syndrome affects both sexes with normal karyotype.

Clinical features:

  • Down-slanting palpebral fissure (antimongoloid slant)
  • Pectus carinatum
  • Hypertelorism
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Low levels of clotting factors 11 and 12
  • Leukemia (Juvenile chronic myelogenous leukemia)
  • Moderate mental retardation in 25%
  • Cardiac abnormality: Most common is pulmonary valve stenosis.
    • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
    • Atrial septal defect
    • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Short stature, webbed neck, low set ears, cubitus valgus (similarities with Turner syndrome)
  • Ptosis, micrognathia, clinodactyly, delayed puberty.

questions.text: A child of age 5 years presents with developmental delay and multiple seizure types. The seizures could not be controlled with multiple drugs. EEG shows1-2 Hz spike and slow waves and polyspike bursts in sleep. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.

It typically starts between the ages of 2 and 10 years of age. Consists of a triad of

    • Developmental delay
    • Multiple seizure types (includes atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures)
    • EEG findings 1-2 Hz spike–and– slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness

 

Patients commonly have myoclonic, atonic, and other seizure types that are difficult to control, and most are left with long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies.

Other options:

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome) typically, it starts in early adolescence (NOT in childhood). The EEG usually shows generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike–and–slow- wave discharges (NOT 1-2 Hz spike–and– slow waves)

Landau-Kleffner syndrome is a rare condition characterized by loss of language skills attributed to auditory agnosia in a previously normal child (NOT a child with developmental delay)

West syndrome starts between the ages of 2 and 12 months (NOT in childhood). Typical EEG picture called hypsarrhythmia (NOT 1-2 Hz spike–and– slow waves, polyspike bursts)

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy with severe intellectual disability underwent a genetic analysis. He was found to have trinucleotide expansion mutations in the FMR-1 gene. Which of the following is not a morphological feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 16-year-old boy with severe intellectual disability and trinucleotide expansion mutations on the FMR-1 gene is suggestive of fragile X syndrome. Patients with Fragile X syndrome have macro-orchidism, not micro-orchidism. 

Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked disorder and the second most common cause of intellectual disability in males after Down syndrome. It is caused by the inactivation of FMR-1 gene due to CGG base repeats on the long arm of the X chromosome.

The characteristic phenotypic features of Fragile X syndrome include the following:

  • Long face with a large mandible
  • Large everted ears
  • Large testicles (macro-orchidism) - observed in at least 90% of affected post-pubertal males.

In some cases, hyperextensible joints, a high-arched palate, and mitral valve prolapse may also be noted. Neuropsychiatric features include intellectual disability, aggressive behaviour, autism spectrum disorder, epilepsy, and anxiety/hyperactivity disorders.

Note: Anticipation is the phenomenon seen in Fragile X syndrome where the disease phenotype worsens over generations within a family.

Other common trinucleotide repeat mutations and their associated conditions:

  • GAA- Friedreich ataxia
  • CAG- Huntington's disease
  • CTG- Myotonic dystrophy

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of electron microscopy finding and disease is incorrect?

choices.text: Linear deposits along the basement membrane - Goodpasture syndrome
Mesangial and paramesangial dense deposits - IgA nephropathy

questions.solution:
Basket-weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is seen in the case of Alport syndrome. 

Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis is a genetic disease caused by mutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen. This is a major component of the basement membranes. The majority of the patients have an X-linked inheritance. Clinical features include hematuria, proteinuria, and sensorineural hearing loss. Ocular manifestations include anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, and corneal dystrophy.

Light microscopy appears normal during the first decade of life. Later glomeruli may have mesangial proliferation and capillary wall thickening. This may lead to progressive sclerosis of the glomerulus. Electron microscopy shows diffuse thickening and thinning along with splitting of glomerular and tubular basement membranes. It is seen as a characteristic basket weaving appearance of lamina densa as shown below.

No specific therapy is recommended to treat Alport syndrome. Proteinuria can be treated with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin 2 receptor blockers.

Subepithelial deposits are seen on electron microscopy in cases of membranous nephropathy. It typically has a noninflammatory pathology. It presents as a nephrotic syndrome in most patients. Non-nephrotic proteinuria, hematuria, and mild hypertension can be seen in some cases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes for evaluation of 3 spontaneous abortions, all of which occurred at <10 weeks gestation. Laboratory tests show the presence of anticardiolipin antibodies. Which of the following is the cause of recurrent pregnancy loss?

choices.text: Placenta overlying the internal cervical os

questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is indicative of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. The mechanism of recurrent pregnancy loss in this scenario is due to thrombosis of the uteroplacental vascular bed.

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder that is one of the common causes of recurrent pregnancy loss. Antiphospholipid antibodies cause oxidative damage to the endothelium, which leads to thrombosis of the vascular bed.

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least 1 clinical criterion and 1 laboratory criterion:

  • Clinical criteria
    • Obstetric
      • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks, or
      • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks, or
      • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
    • Vascular
      • One or more episodes of arterial, venous, or small-vessel thrombosis in any tissue 
  • Laboratory criteria: Presence of any of following
    • Lupus anticoagulant
    • Anticardiolipin antibodies
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein antibody

In cases with recurrent pregnancy loss and confirmed diagnosis, low-dose aspirin with unfractionated or low-molecular-weight heparin is given. These drugs are started at the time of diagnosis and given until 6 weeks postpartum.

Other Options:

Option A: Cervical insufficiency is characterized by painless cervical dilation in the second trimester.

Option B: Overt hypothyroidism also causes recurrent abortion. The patient would have symptoms such as dry skin, cold intolerance, hair loss, constipation, weight gain with poor appetite.

Option D: Placenta previa is a condition in which the placenta is implanted at the lower uterine segment. The patient presents with painless, apparently causeless vaginal bleeding after the 28th week. The early pregnancy loss (<10 weeks) in this case rules out placeta previa.

Note: The new 2023 ACR/EULAR criteria, is an update from the revised Sapporo criteria with the clinical criteria divided into 6 domains and each metric in the clinical and laboratory value adding a weighted score. This has increased the specificity in diagnosing APS.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with dyspnea. She had been complaining of fatigue and worsening dyspnoea over the last 3-5 days. Examination revealed BP of 80/50 mmHg, tachypnea, tachycardia, elevated neck veins, and muffled heart sounds. The echocardiography finding is shown below. Which of the following findings is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation with the classic Beck's triad and the echo showing the swinging heart sign are indicative of the diagnosis being cardiac tamponade. Physical examination would reveal the presence of pulsus paradoxus in this patient.

This patient has the classic Beck's triad of cardiac tamponade:

  • Hypotension
  • Muffled heart sounds
  • Raised jugular venous pressure (elevated neck veins) with a prominent x descent(early systolic) but an absent y(early diastolic)descent. 

The echocardiography shows swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade. The pericardial pressures exceed the left ventricular diastolic filling pressures, causing the collapse of the left ventricular free wall during diastole.

Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration. In cardiac tamponade, the ventricles are covered by an incompressible pericardial sac with increased pressure in the pericardial sac. Increased blood flows into the right ventricle during inspiration causes the interventricular septum to bulge into the left ventricle, which in turn causes a reduction in left ventricular volume, stroke volume, and arterial blood pressure. This inspiratory fall in systolic pressure is an exaggerated consequence of interventricular dependence. Severe cases may show weakening or disappearance of arterial pulse on palpation during inspiration.

Other causes of pulsus paradoxus include:

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Severe obstructive lung disease
  • Hemorrhagic shock

ECG in a patient with cardiac tamponade shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electrical alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction. When the heart is nearer to the chest wall, the amplitude deflection on the ECG is increased; in contrast, when the heart moves away from the chest wall, the amplitude deflection is lower. 

 

Management of cardiac tamponade -   Intravenous infusion of normal saline improves the cardiac haemodynamics in a significant proportion of tamponade patients. The best course of action is performing pericardiocentesis, preferably carried out under echocardiographic guidance. In cases of recurrent tamponade, a small catheter may be left in place to drain subsequent collections of fluid. 

Other options:

Option B: Pulsus bisferiens also known as bifid pulse has two systolic peaks. It is seen in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. There is a rapid upstroke to the first peak (percussion wave) and a slower rise to the second peak (tidal wave). It is also rarely appreciated in patients with severe aortic regurgitation.

Option C: Pulsus parvus et tardus refers to a weak pulse (parvus), which rises slowly to a delayed peak (tardus) seen in aortic stenosis.

Option D: Pulsus alternans is defined as beat-to-beat variability in the amplitude of the pulse. It is seen in patients with severe LV dysfunction.

questions.text: A 65-year-old obese woman presented with vomiting, abdominal distension, and obstipation. She had recurrent episodes of such complaints for the past few days. An erect abdominal X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following is most likely to be related to the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia) and multiple air-fluid levels, which indicates small bowel obstruction. This finding along with the clinical scenario is suggestive of gallstone ileus. Rigler’s triad is associated with this condition.

Rigler’s triad comprises of:

  1. Small bowel obstruction (multiple air-fluid levels)
  2. Pneumobilia (gas in the biliary tract)
  3. Atypical mineral shadow on the abdominal radiographs (ectopic gallstone)

Given below is a plain x-ray of the erect abdomen showing air in the biliary tract (pneumobilia).

Gallstone ileus is a condition caused by the obstruction of the intestinal lumen by a gallstone, leading to a mechanical blockage. The most common site of blockage is the terminal ileum before entering the cecum. It usually presents with symptoms of intestinal obstruction (abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, distention, and obstipation) in patients with a history of gallstones.

Large-sized gallstones will not be able to pass through the normal cystic duct. This causes inflammation of the gallbladder and results in pressure necrosis. This in turn leads to biliary-enteric fistula formation resulting in a triad of features known as Rigler’s triad.

The patient may have constant pain or recurrent episodic discomfort from the intestinal obstruction which may be incomplete. CT scan is helpful in the diagnosis. This condition is managed by laparotomy and milking the stone proximally away from the site of impaction. The stone is tried to be crushed within the bowel lumen or the intestine is opened at that point to remove the gallstone.

Other options:

Quincke's triad is seen in hemobilia. It comprises upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage, abdominal pain, and obstructive jaundice.

Borchardt triad is seen in gastric volvulus. It comprises a sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain, recurrent retching with minimal vomitus and inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube.

Saint's triad comprises hiatus hernia, gallstones, and colonic diverticulosis.

Note: Obstipation is the failure to pass both flatus and faeces.
